message: Dears,currently we are creating a form generation for medical application and sure data and schema is very dynamic , so we are thinking to work with NoSQL database to store the information as it is document based and schemaless , what do you recommend MongoDB or CouchDB ? is server management for these dbs is complex as the deployment could be over intranet or shall i go for Amazon Dynamodb and force them to work over internet (Which in some cases could be hard )? your recommendations are highly appreciated

data.message:
I would make it with SQL, something like : 

FieldTypes:
Id
Name
RegexExpressionOrIdOrSQLType..etc

Forms:
Id
Name

FieldTypeId
FieldLabel
DisplayOrder

Id
FormFieldId
RegexExpressionOrId

أظن من غير سكيما هتعك أوي وتكون صعبه وبطيئه في عمل تقارير واحصائيات حلوه والخ لما الداتا تكبر، ساعات باتعامل مع قواعد بيانات زي اللي إنت عايز تعملها وغالبا بتكون مقرفه مثلا لو أنا عايز أجيب إيميلات كل الناس من كل الفورمز مش باقدر بسهوله لأن فيلدات الإيميل في كل فورم مختلفة مثلا وباسماء مختلفة والخ وحاجات كتير من دي، بس إنت عموما أدرى بالنظام اللي بتعمله

What you added is how to create the form , this isn't the issue is on saving information and loading the information inside each form , it could be done in SQL by adding JSON objects in DB but it will be big headache in search and slow for serialization and deserialization

Mongo has a serious problems with Performance. you should check the performance issues before planning ahead :)
PostgreSQL is a relational DB which supports json & hstore (hash store) data types with good performance, so you get the best of both worlds.
I second on PostgreSQL + hstore. If you prefer something closer to NoSql, pick RethinkDB. Don't make MongoDB as your primary store.
I will use the NoSQl specifically for this part only in the system else i m using SQL Server
PostgreSQL HStore is now has semantic equivalent to JSON support (string, bool and number) http://www.sai.msu.su/~megera/postgres/talks/hstore-dublin-2013.pdf

My friend what you are going to decide upon is are u archiving more or retrieving more as insertion is way to slow with NoSQL approach but selection is way faster so that's a one So "I guess No SQL" then as u are using a userbase so what u really need is graph database or graph approach by a noaql database so I reccomend Neo4j or Mongodb if u are going outside these 2 approaches you are going to suffer a lot in documentation .. Mongo is about to be Visual studio partner and well defined by MVP like Scott Scott Allen
but I used Neo4j as it has a well maintained service from readify which I trust from previous exp
It wouldn't make sense to use a Graph DB for document oriented data.
Well you can use Graph to describe pretty much everything. If you can just stuff all your data in one document, then that's ideal. You just have to worry about one thing.
